The complete distilling apparatus consists of three parts: the ‚Äúcucurbit‚Äù (Arabic ·∏≥ar øa, Greek Œ≤ŒØŒ∫ŒøœÇ), the still pot containing the liquid to be distilled, which is heated by a flame; the ‚Äúhead‚Äù or ‚Äúcap‚Äù (Arabic anbi·∏≥, Greek ·ºÑŒºŒ≤ŒπŒæ) which fits over the mouth of the cucurbit to receive the vapors, with an attached downward-sloping ‚Äútube‚Äù (Greek œÉœâŒªŒÆŒΩ), leading to the ‚Äúreceiver‚Äù (Arabic ·∏≥ƒÅbila, Greek ·ºÑŒ≥Œ≥ŒøœÇ or œÜŒπŒ¨ŒªŒ∑) container.



Retorts have the ‚Äúcap‚Äù and the ‚Äúcucurbit‚Äù made into one. The anbik is also called the ra æs (head) of the cucurbit. The liquid in the cucurbit is heated or boiled; the vapour rises into the anbik, where it cools by contact with the walls and condenses, running down the spout into the receiver. A modern descendant of the alembic is the pot still, used to produce distilled beverages.

title: History of the Alembic
excerpt: Dioscorides‚Äô ambix (described in his De materia medica) is a helmet-shaped lid for gathering condensed mercury. For Athenaeus (~ 225 C.E.) it is a bottle or flask. For later chemists it denotes various parts of crude distillation devices.
content:
Dioscorides‚Äô ambix (described in his De materia medica) is a helmet-shaped lid for gathering condensed mercury. For Athenaeus (~ 225 C.E.) it is a bottle or flask. For later chemists it denotes various parts of crude distillation devices.



Alembic drawings appear in works of Cleopatra the Alchemist, Synesius, and Zosimos of Panopolis. There were alembics with two (dibikos) and three (tribikos) receivers.[4] According to Zosimos of Panopolis, the alembic was invented by Mary the Jewess.[5]

The anbik is described by Ibn al-Awwam in his Kitab al-Filaha (Book of Agriculture), where he explains how rose-water is distilled. Amongst others, it is mentioned in the Mafatih al-Ulum (Key of Sciences) of Khwarizmi and the Kitab al-Asrar (Book of Secrets) of Al-Razi. Some illustrations occur in the Latin translations of works which are attributed to Geber.[2]

title: Description of a Pot Still
excerpt: A pot still is a type of still used in distilling spirits such as whisky or brandy. Heat is applied directly to the pot containing the wash (for whisky) or wine (for brandy).
content:
A pot still is a type of still used in distilling spirits such as whisky or brandy. Heat is applied directly to the pot containing the wash (for whisky) or wine (for brandy). This is called a batch distillation (as opposed to a continuous distillation).

At standard atmospheric pressure, alcohol boils at 78 ¬∞C (172 ¬∞F), while water boils at 100 ¬∞C (212 ¬∞F). During distillation, the vapour contains more alcohol than the liquid. When the vapours are condensed, the resulting liquid contains a higher concentration of alcohol. In the pot still, the alcohol and water vapour combine with esters and flow from the still through the condensing coil. There they condense into the first distillation liquid, the so-called ‚Äúlow wines‚Äù. The low wines have a strength of about 25‚Äì35% alcohol by volume, and flow into a second still. It is then distilled a second time to produce the colourless spirit, collected at about 70% alcohol by volume. Colour is added through maturation in an oak aging barrel, and develops over time.

The modern pot still is a descendant of the alembic, an earlier distillation device.

Overview

Inputs and outputs of UVengine.



Features


  A variability resolution engine for UVL models.
  Support all language level extensions of UVL.
  Feature traceability between UVL models and implementation artifacts.
  Language independence for any text-based artifacts using Jinja templates.
  Composition and annotation-based mechanisms to implement variability at different degrees of granularity.
  Easy integration with existing tools of the UVL ecosystem such as UVLS and flamapy.
